title: labour asks civil service chief
story: Labour asks civil service chief to call in police over No  Christmas partiesAngela Rayner demanded answers over explosive claims that No  hosted social gatherings in the run up to last Christmas - while millions were living under Covid curbsBoris Johnson switches on the Downing Street Christmas lights on Wednesday Image: Andrew Parsons   No Downing StreetByPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political Editor:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsLabouraposs deputy leader has asked the Governmentaposs top civil servant whether he will call in the politan Police to investigate the Downing Street parties row.In a letter to Simon Case, Angela Rayner demanded answers over explosive claims that No  hosted social gatherings in breach of lockdown rules in the run-up to last Christmas. Amid the fall-out of The Mirroraposs exclusive story, she asked whether the Cabinet Secretary had been aware of the gatherings that were taking place. Ms Rayner wanted to knowhe would be conducting an internal investigation into the use of Government property for the parties and the role played by Boris Johnson and his officials. The Labour deputy leader wrote: You will no doubt understand the seriousness of the allegations made. This Government is undermining public health messaging with their actions and we cannot let this go on unchecked. It cannot be that the Prime Minister believes there to be a set of rules for the public and a totally dferent set of rules for himself. Mr Johnson and his Downing Street staff have been accused of breaking Covid rules by attending parties at Number  in the run-up to last Christmas. The Prime Minister gave a speech at a packed leaving do for a top aide last November when the country was in the grip of its second lockdown. Then just days before Christmas, with London in tier  restrictions, members of his top team held their own festive bash in Downing Street. It is alleged that officials knocked back glasses of wine during a yuletide quiz and a Secret Santa while the rest of the country was forced to stay at home. The following day the PM aposcancelledapos Christmas for millions of people across the country.Mr Johnson refused three times to deny that the boozy parties had taken place when pressed at PMQs.  No  has claimed that Covid rules were followed at all times. But a Downing Street insider claimed there were often evening get-togethers while millions of people were observing the strict curbs imposed by the PM. The source said: “It was the only place you could get together and socialise. They happened most Fridays.” The Covid- Bereaved Families for Justice group slammed the PM, who faced demands to apologise for what appears to be a clear breach of his own rules. Member Safiah Ngah lost her father Zahari, , to the virus in February. The -year-old said: “Last Christmas is sadly one I will never forget. “One in  people in my borough had Covid- and my family were desperately trying to do what we could to keep each other safe. Unfortunately it wasn’t enough. To think that just a few miles away, Boris Johnson was throwing a ‘Christmas party’, with no care for the rules he had set, is sickening.“In September, he looked bereaved families in the eye and told them he had done ‘everything he could to keep their loved ones safe’. How exactly did breaking the rules himself fit into that  “While he was enjoying an illegal Christmas party, the people he should have been protecting were dying all around the country.” “The first thing the Prime Minister must do is acknowledge the hurt this has caused, and apologise.” Read MoreRead MoreMost ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Labour Partypolitan PolicePoliticsCoronavirusBoris Johnson" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news politics magical-time-year-special-smell-"Johnson responds to accusations of  Tory Christmas partyopinionByPolly Hudson:,  Dec | commentsIt’s that magical time of year, and there’s a special smell in the air. Mince pies baking  Mulled wine simmering  Nope, it’s the stench of utter hypocrisy… yet again. It takes quite something to make Matt Hancock look good – and he still doesn’t, but at least he resigned when caught breaking Covid rules. Boris Johnson instead appears to be adopting the approach of frenemy Dominic Cummings. He and his staff only attended crowded parties during lockdown to test their eyesight, presumably. We all tried to make the best of it, and hark back to Blitz Spirit and the like, but Christmas  was terrible. At best. At worst it was devastating, and tragic, because many were robbed of sharing a loved one’s last ever festive season. That the restrictions were necessary didn’t make them any less painful or easier to endure. The only thing that made the depressing damp squib of a yuletide in any way bearable was the knowledge that we were all in the same boat. So to find out now that a select few REDACT  or  were in fact enjoying Christmas perks like packed parties featuring festive quizzes and enough booze to make a festive quiz seem fun is just too much. Brings a whole new meaning to the term Secret Santa, doesn’t it   Once again, it’s a case of Do As I Say Not As I Do from this hideously corrupt bunch, who do not deny that these parties took place, but insist that “rules were followed.” Something of a contradiction in terms seeing as the rules literally were that these parties could not take place. Just like when the Johnsons were caught having an overnight guest during the peak of lockdown last Christmas, presumably the Prime Minister now considers this matter closed. Remember, he only begs for forgiveness when he loses his place in a speech about Peppa Pig. title: old bexley sidcup byelection result
story: Bexley by-election result: Tories hold safe seat but with % swing to LabourTory candidate Louie French won the Old Bexley and Sidcup by-election - but with a reduced majority - in a vote triggered by the death of MP James BrokenshireConservative candidate Louie French celebrates victory in the Old Bexley and Sidcup by-election Image: PAByLizzy BuchanDeputy Online Political Editor:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsThe Tories held a safe seat in a suburban London stronghold but saw its majority of nearly , slashed to just , - with a swing of % to Labour - amid low turnout. Conservative Louie French took more than half the votes in the Old Bexley and Sidcup by-election, while only a third of those eligible to vote took part in the contest triggered by the death of Tory MP James Brokenshire in October.The turn-out was %, with , votes cast, down from almost % at the snap general election two years ago, when , votes were cast.The Conservatives expected to retain the constituency despite a bruising few weeks for Boris Johnson’s administration.The contest took place following damaging headlines over allegations of sleaze, claims that lockdown rules were broken in No  and the emergence of the Omicron coronavirus iant.Mr French was the bookmakers’ firm favourite to win the election, with Labour acknowledging that they did not expect an upset.  In his acceptance speech shortly after am on Friday, the new MP said: “I’m incredibly proud of the campaign my team and I have run based on local issues that matter to the people who live here. “And tonight, those people send a clear message: they want an MP who will work with the Government to deliver on their priorities. “My focus will now be delivering on those promises that I made during the campaign – get our fair share of London’s police officers, securing more investment for local schools and hospitals, protecting our precious green spaces.” He promised voters he would “work tirelessly to repay the trust that you’ve placed in me and I will not let you down”. Mr French, a local councillor, said he was the first home-grown MP for the seat. “This is the greatest honour of my le. And I hope it inspires people to achieve their own dreams.  Ellie Reeves, Labour MP for Lewisham West and Penge, said: “We’re pleased with the result tonight.“This is a Conservative stronghold, somewhere that had a , majority at the last general election and what we’ve seen tonight is that majority being slashed. There’s been a % swing over to Labour this evening.“We’ve been knocking on doors for weeks here and finding many, many Conservative voters that have said actually I’m not going to vote for them this time, I’m going to vote for Labour. “I think it’s clear that we’re winning back the trust of people and it’s a remarkable result for us in a Tory stronghold.” Restricting the Conservatives to less than % of the vote would be “great”, a Labour source said before the result was announced. A party official dismissed the suggestion from Conservative deputy chair Justin Tomlinson that Labour would have to run the Tories “very, very close”it was serious about being an alternative government.  They said: “No Conservative candidate has every got below % in this seat. If we can get them down to %, that will be great.” Mr French’s share of more than % of the vote is “almost unheard of”, the Conservative deputy chairman has said. Justin Tomlinson said: “We’re absolutely thrilled. For a Government to get over % of the vote in a parliamentary by-election is almost unheard of, and with a majority of over %. “A fantastic local candidate, positive campaign, focused on the tangible dference we’re making to people’s lives, having navigated the unprecedented challenges of Covid.” He added that the result was an “absolute disaster” for the Labour Party, saying: “They do not look like a Government in waiting.” Reform leader Richard Tice came in third, claiming his party was now “on the upward march”. A string of senior Tories, including the Prime Minister, have visited the constituency during the by-election campaign, with Transport Secretary Grant Shapps among the MPs bolstering the effort to get out the vote on Thursday. But a turnout of just % suggests the by-election contest has failed to excite the public in the constituency. Labour also had a high-profile on the streets of Old Bexley and Sidcup, with shadow chancellor Rachel Reeves and her sister and shadow solicitor general Ellie among those knocking on doors on polling day on behalf of candidate Daniel Francis. Former Cabinet minister Mr Brokenshire, who had represented the constituency since , was diagnosed with early stage lung cancer in . He held the seat in  with a large majority of , votes. A defeat in the by-election would have been a major blow for Mr Johnson, who has suffered a hit in the polls following weeks of sleaze allegations and political blunders. The constituency has always had a Conservative MP since it was created in . Former Tory Prime Minister Ted Heath held the seat - and its predecessor, Bexley - for  years.The last time Labour won in the constituency was in a  by-election. The seat is in the outer-London boroughs where the Tories and Liberal Democrats are traditionally successful. However Labour would expect to face criticismit failed to cut the Conservative majority, on what is expected to be a low turnout. Tributes poured in from across politics to Mr Brokenshire on his death in October at just -years-old. The popular MP was hailed by many for his kindness and decency. He was first diagnosed with cancer in  and resigned as Northern Ireland Secretary to have lung surgery. He ed to Parliament only five weeks later.Mr Brokenshire was made Housing Secretary from April  to July , and he was named as Security Minister in  by Boris Johnson. He took a leave of absence in January  to prepare for another operation, and resigned in July after struggling with his recovery. Mr Brokenshire, who had never smoked, announced in August that the cancer had progressed and he was starting a new line of treatment. Announcing his death in October, his family said in a statement: It is with deep sadness that we announce the death of James Brokenshire MP at the age of . James died peacefully at Darent Valley Hospital yesterday evening with family members by his bedside. He had been in hospital since Sunday after his condition rapidly deteriorated. James was not only a brilliant Government minister as both Security and Immigration Minister at the Home Office and Secretary of State at the Northern Ireland Office and Ministry for Housing, Communities  Local Government, but a dedicated constituency MP, first for Hornchurch from  to , and then for Old Bexley  Sidcup for the past  years. But most importantly, he was a loving father to his three children, a devoted husband to Cathy and a faithful friend to so many. Full results The full results of the Old Bexley and Sidcup by-election are:Conservative hold. Louie French, Daniel Francis, Richard Tice, Jonathan Rooks Simone Reynolds Elaine Cheeseman John Poynton Richard Hewison David Kurten Carol Valinejad Mad Mike Young Conservative majority ,.% swing Conservative to Labour. news politics sajid-javid-says-snog-who-"Sajid Javid: People should snog who they want under the mistletoeByLizzy BuchanDeputy Online Political Editor:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsThe Health Secretary has declared people can snog who they wish this Christmas - after another top Tory told Brits not to kiss strangers under the mistletoe. Sajid Javid said it was not up to the Government to decide who people can kiss amid growing confusion over Covid guidance this Christmas.New restrictions have been brought in to tackle the Omicron iant, including mandatory masks in shops and on public transport, and PCR tests for all arrivals from abroad.But ministers have sowed confusion by saying wildly dferent things about the guidance - which is voluntary rather than a legal requirement - on things like social contact.Work and Pensions Secretary Therese Coffey told Brits that snogging under the mistletoe should be avoided with people you donapost already know on Wednesday night. But Mr Javid disagreed, telling ITV News today itaposs got nothing to do with the government who you kiss, when asked about how people should behave over the Christmas period.He said: People can snog who they wish. Iaposll certainly be kissing my we under the mistletoe, itaposs a Javid family tradition and itaposs got nothing to do with the government who you kiss, or anything like that. Thereaposs guidance already out there, just be cautious and enjoy yourselves. He did not expand on what he meant by being cautious. Labour leader Keir Starmer also said he didnapost think it was for the Government to dictate who people can kiss or not kiss.I was quite surprised to see that suggestion come out of Government, he told ITV. I think it just demonstrates how they are at sixes and ninesthataposs what they are now discussing. No said of Ms Coffey’s comments: “It is down to iniduals to use their personal judgement”. Earlier this week, top official Dr Jenny Harries enraged Tory backbenchers by saying people should reduce their social contacts and avoid socialising when we donapost particularly need to.  Boris Johnson later contradicted her and said events did not need to be cancelled.But then Tory Minister George Freeman muddied the waters by appearing to suggest people should not have big Christmas parties.He told the BBC : Inidual businesses, in the end, have to make judgments on what is appropriate internally.“It slightly depends on the nature of the business. “For many small businesses, four or five staff, who are working together every day anyway, gathering to have a drink isnapost a big step up in risk. “But some companies might normally bring hundreds of people in from around the world to a big party, and they may decide, this year, is that sensible given the pandemic and given where we are  Mr Freeman also told Times Radio: I can tell you the Department of Business, we wonapost be having a big Christmas party this year. Nobody would expect us to. Later on Thursday, Mr Johnson again insisted that people did not need to cancel their festive plans.  Speaking to broadcasters after having his booster jab in London, the PM said: I want to repeat the guidance is there and Iaposm very, very keen that people understand this, we donapost want people to feel that they need to start cancelling things, to start... you talk about kids in nativity plays and that kind of thing. I donapost think thereaposs any need to stop that at all.I think weaposre taking a balanced and proportionate approach to the risk, but I want and I believe that Christmas this year will be considerably better than Christmas last year.Boss of pub group Youngaposs Patrick Dardis said some Christmas parties had already been cancelled amid concerns over the Omicron iant.He said: I think the messaging has been terribly confusing and inconsistent. news politics tories-told-make-your-mind-"Sajid Javid: People should snog who they want under the mistletoeByBen GlazeDeputy Political EditorDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | comments Christmas plans were in chaos tonight as No gave ­conflicting messages over festive parties. Boris Johnson insisted they should go ahead before a business minister urged them to be scrapped. One pub boss said: “It’s terribly confusing.”With Christmas approaching, families and ­festive revellers are desperate to know what they can or cannot do as the Omicron iant threat grows.But the public were left none the wiser tonight after a stream of mixed messages poured out of Downing Street, from advice on parties to kissing under mistletoe. And the muddled advice caused further outrage among a public already furious at No for holding parties last year during lockdown.  Amid fears get-togethers could spark a surge of the latest Covid iant, Boris Johnson insisted no one should cancel yuletide bashes. But hours earlier, Business Minister George Freeman sug­­gested that larger firms should scrap Christmas parties. The confusion grew further today as Work and Pensions Secretary Therese Coffey warned “snogging under the mistletoe” should be avoided with strangers. But Health Secretary Sajid Javid said tonight: “People can snog who they wish.  “It’s got nothing to do with the Government who you kiss. There’s guidance out there, just be cautious and enjoy yourselves.” Mr Johnson, who today had his booster jab at St Thomas’ Hospital in South London, insisted “we want people to continue as they are”. He added: “People should follow the g­uidance that we’ve set out and people shouldn’t be cancelling things, and there’s no need for that at all.” But Mr Freeman cast doubt on works parties. He said: “Inidual businesses must make judgments on what is appropriate ­internally. It depends on the nature of the ­business. “For small businesses, four or five staff, who work together every day anyway, gathering to have a drink isn’t a big step up in risk. But some companies might normally bring hundreds of people in from around the world to a big party, and they may decide is that sensible given the pandemic and given where we are ”  Adding to the lack of clarity, Mr Freeman insisted his Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy would not be having a “big” festive bash – just weeks after Secretary of State Kwasi Kwarteng said a party was already booked. He added: “Nobody would expect us to. My parliamentary team, I think we’ve agreed, ­probably given the new iant, we’ll get together on Zoom and toast each other.” Mr Kwarteng had said on October : “We’ve got some arrangements in place, and I look forward to having a Christmas party as usual.” A Business Department source today said “dferent teams do dferent things” and no single party for BEIS had been planned. It is understood Mr Kwarteng’s bash is still going ahead. The boss of pub group Young’s revealed some parties had already been cancelled due to the confusion. Patrick Dardis said: “I think the messaging has been terribly confusing and inconsistent. “One moment we’re told to avoid socialising and an hour later you have Sajid Javid saying the opposite. “I think the messaging started as a complete ­overreaction and, unsurprisingly, it has concerned some people.” Royal College of Nursing Council chairwoman Carol Popplestone said the “mixed messages” from ministers over Christmas plans could create “even more worry and confusion”. Shadow Business Secretary­ ­Jonathan Reynolds urged revellers to take Covid tests before parties. But he added: “I don’t want to see people cancelling parties now. “People need to live their lives and have some fun but also it has a huge impact on things like the hospitality industry.” A further seven cases of Omicron were confirmed today in England and three in Scotland, the UK Health Security Agency said. It brings the total to . Up  people are believed to have been infected with the iant after a festive party in Norway, the world’s largest outbreak so far. The mixed messages Kissing under the mistletoe Cabinet minister Therese Coffey said: “I don’t think there should be much snogging under the mistletoe.” Askedthere should be “just no snogging ”, she replied: “Well, not with people you don’t already know.” But Health Secretary Sajid Javid declared that people can “snog who they wish” this festive season.  Big Xmas parties Minister George Freeman appeared to be freelancing when he suggested that big firms could cancel their festive bashes. He said: “Some companies might normally bring hundreds of people around the world to a big party. And they may decide this year ‘is that sensible ’” But No  said: “On Christmas parties, we don’t want people to cancel such events.” Socialising Dr Jenny Harries, of the UK Health Security Agency, said “not socialising when we don’t particularly need to” over Christmas could keep the virus at bay. But Boris Johnson rejected the advice, adding: “On Christmas parties and nativity plays, we don’t want people to cancel events.”  Testing Mr Javid tracked close to the official guidance on tests but that only went to show how vague it is. He said there wasn’t “any need to change” Covid rules but said he’d take a lateral flow test before going to a party. “If you are invited to a Christmas party, there’s quite a few people there, maybe you want to take an LFT before you go,” he said. “Go to the party but just be cautious.” Read MoreRead MoreMost ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Christmas partyPoliticsCoronavirusTory GovernmentCoronavirus lockdown" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: tory mp declares 60k third
story: Tory MP declares £k third job after pledging Parliament would be full timeThe latest Register of Members Interests reveals the MP for Stevenage now puts more time in as a strategic adviser for MBU Capital Group, for which he will be paid £, a month Image: Internet UnknownByMikey SmithWhitehall Correspondent:,  Dec | commentsA Tory MP has declared a £, third job giving aposstrategic adviceapos to a private firm - despite claiming being an MP would be his aposfull-time jobapos. Steven McPartland already works ten hours a month as a non-executive director of Furniture Village, from which he pockets more than £, a month. But the latest Register of Membersapos Interests reveals the MP for Stevenage now puts more time in as a strategic adviser for MBU Capital Group, for which he will be paid £, a month. According to National World, MBU Capital Group is a London-based financial firm which invests in national resources, education, cannabis CBD and real estate. He took the new job on  November , and according to the register, expects to work for eight hours a month - which amounts to £ an hour.  Mr McPartland, shortly before his election in , promised: “If I became Stevenageaposs MP, I would treat it as a full-time job.” Boris Johnson has promised an overhaul of the rules governing MPs outside earnings - banning MPs from “exploiting their positions” by working as paid consultants. But Labour have argued his plans don’t go far enough, and pledged to ban all second jobs for MPs, with just a few exemptions.It emerged last night that a string of Tory MPs had given up their second jobs in the wake of the scandal. The latest register of members interests shows former chief whip Julian Smith has given up paid roles worth more than £, a year. They include Hygen Energy - a green fuel firm founded by Jo Bamford, the son of JCB mogul and major Tory donor Sir Anthony Bamford - which paid him up to £, a year as an “external adviser advising on business development”. Former Tory leader Sir Iain Duncan Smith’s register has been updated to show he is no longer a member of the advisory board of healthcare tech firm Tunstall. And Winchester MP Steve Brine’s record has been updated to say he has stepped back as a “strategic adviser” to Sigma pharmaceuticals. title: aldi boss makes urgent christmas
story: Aldi boss makes urgent Christmas plea to every Brit who shops at the supermarketAldi CEO Giles Hurley has made an urgent appeal to every shopper who heads into the one of stores belonging to the supermarket giant this festive period that they respect the Covid rulesAldi CEO Giles Hurley has made an urgent appeal to every shopper over the festive period Image: Bloomberg via Getty ImagesByRachel PughTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Dec | commentsAldiaposs boss has appealed for Christmas shoppers to once again step up and follow Covid restrictions that have been put back in place for everyone’s safety. The supermarket giant has taken the unusual step to publish an email where the CEO Giles Hurley has asked for people to think about each other and not take risks over Covid during the festive period when shopping.Hurley said that restrictions are being put in for the benefit of staff and customers, reported the Manchester Evening News. As we head into the festive season, I want to personally thank you for your ongoing support, he said in an email. Working together, we have continued to make changes to protect you and our colleagues, who have worked tirelessly to ensure all of our customers can get everything they need from Aldi.  The email went on to outline the new guidelines that will see facemasks obligatory in Aldi stores. He said: I am writing to you today to reassure you that following the latest government guidance, masks are again compulsory in all of our stores across the UK, unless you have a medical exemption. We are asking all customers to be responsible and follow this guidance when shopping with us. Our Aldi colleagues will also be doing their bit by wearing masks too, as they have throughout this year. The Aldi boss also explained the measures that the stores have in place to help limit the spread of Covid. In addition, all of the comprehensive safety measures you will be used to seeing in store will continue to be in place, he said.  We have protective screens at all , of our checkouts. All stores have sanitisation stations for customer use. There are clear signs reminding customers to wear a face covering and shop responsibly. “We have separate entrances and exits in place. We are encouraging payment by card or contactless when possible, with an increased contactless limit of £. At the same time, the email outlined opening times: The majority of our stores are open from am – pm every dayand our amazing colleagues are on hand to help you shop safely and find everything you need. Giles added: So as we prepare for Christmas, I hope that you, your friends and family are well, and we look forward to seeing you at Aldi over the coming weeks. The supermarket has issued the email at the same time as the government has stepped in to increase Covid restrictions following the potential threat posed by the new iant Omicron. title: bar doorman asked is angela
story: Bar doorman frequently asked is Angela in tonight explains how he helps womenThe code phrase is part of the Ask Angela campaign aimed at helping women who feel unsafe, vulnerable or threatened in bars, clubs and other night time venues" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _Security-guard-are-regulating-the-situation-of-safety-in-an-event-concert-in-a-nightclub.jpg" width"" "" Anyone who feels vulnerable can approach bar or security staffImage: Getty Images iStockphotoByCharlotte HadfieldDanya BazaraaSenior News Reporter:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsA doorman who has been asked is Angela in tonight on multiple occasions has explained how he helps women in need. The code phrase is part of the Ask Angela campaign aimed at helping people who feel unsafe, vulnerable or threatened in bars, clubs and other night time venues, Liverpool Echo reports. Anyone who feels this way, can approach bar or security staff using the special code word Angela, which indicates to staff that they require help or support.This might be in the form of calling them a taxi, reuniting them with a friend or calling security and or the police. Adam Potter has been asked the question several times since he started his job as doorman in Liverpool city centre five months ago. The -year-old said every night at work he is approached by women who ask him to keep an eye on men who are making them feel uncomfortable on the dancefloor. And when Adam has been asked by women is Angela in tonight , he says he has stepped in to help.  Adam told the Liverpool Echo: They basically say aposcan you keep an eye on this guy heaposs making me feel uncomfortable apos I probably get that at least once a night, possibly three or four times a night - thataposs just girls who come up to me. They might say aposheaposs tapped me on the bottomapos, in which case he gets thrown out. Any touching inappropriately they get thrown out immediately. Adam has spoken out in the hope of raising awareness of the Ask Angela campaign and encouraging other bar staff to learn about the initiative. It comes after a post was shared widely on social media about the importance of the campaign in keeping people safe on nights out. Adam said: What happens is,a girl comes up to you and says aposIs Angela in tonight apos you know exactly what she means. What you then do is say aposyes apossheaposs in tonight just come with me.apos You take her behind the bar into the staff area and phone for a taxi. In more extreme cases, bar staff might have to call the police or security. Adam said: I went into this job basically just to help people and I do my very best but when I hear about girls constantly being harassed and not being as safe as they used to be going out it makes me feel upset. title: ba worker who sacked after
story: BA worker who was sacked after having tumour operation wins £, payoutCordelle Scotland, , had to take time off following an operation and bosses told her to swap her shts - a tribunal ruled she had been treated unfavourably by British AirwaysA tribunal ruled British Airways treated Cordelle Scotland unfavourably Image: REUTERSByNeil ShawAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Dec | commentsA British Airways worker who was sacked after having a tumour operation has won a £, payout from the airline. Cordelle Scotland, , had to take time off following an operation to treat her endometriosis and was told by her boss to try and swap her shts. Cordelle, who worked at Heathrow Airport as a customer services representative, complained after failing her probationary period and was told she had been sacked as she had been late to work several times. A tribunal ruled the airline treated her unfavourably by criticising Cordelle for not swapping shts. The airline was ordered she be paid £, compensation for injury to her feelings.  Cordelle suffered from fibroids and endometriosis, which causes excessive bleeding, a hearing was told. Having worked for BA for eight months and had her probationary period extended due to concern over absences and lateness, she told bosses she needed to undergo surgery for the condition. The tribunal heard Cordelle sent an email in November  explaining: I am due for hospital admission on th December for an abdominal myomectomy due to my fibroids and endometriosis reaching the stage of disability which in turn affects my work and le in general greatly.To put it into perspective, my uterus is the same size as a five and a half month pregnancy due to the tumours.The recovery period is about  weeks however I have concerns as to how this may affect my probation. I need to have this surgery on this date as I have been having treatment for the last three months to help shrink the fibroids before surgery and it is not recommended for me to continue the treatment any longer than three months as it has induced me into menopause which can trigger osteoporosis. My third and last treatment will be on the th November. As a result, she was signed off by her GP for two weeks from December . When her probationary period ended in February , Cordelle was told her employment would be terminated as your attendance level is unacceptable and you have been late to work on  separate occasions between March  and February . In an email, Heathrow Services Manager Nicola Drinkwater added: I have taken into account that you had a planned medical procedure on the th December , which you have been recovering from and signed off work by your GP between th December  - nd February .  However the seasonal roster you were working offers vast amounts of flexibility to swap shts and work on available rest days prior or post your procedure. She also cited a further three occasions of lateness which came after a review meeting in October  that extended Cordelleaposs probationary period due to concerns regarding your attendance and performance. Cordelle then emailed CEO Alex Cruz and Tom Stevens, BAaposs Head of Worldwide Airports, and said she made all attempts to ensure my surgery would not interfere with my employment. She added: For Nikki to then make the statement that I should have sorted my recovery time off with sht swaps and leave is completely unfair and discriminatory. for our daily newsletter to keep up to date with all the essential information atwww.mirror email.My surgery was gynaecological for endometriosisand uterine fibroids . Why should I be expected to have covered recovery time from major surgery with leave and sht swap. Ms Drinkwater told the tribunal Cordelle was sacked for the high number of times she was late and that it was not because of her sickness absence nor the need to be on restricted duties following herto work. Cordelleaposs claims for wrongful dismissal, direct discrimination because of race and or sex and or disability were dismissed by the tribunal. It also ruled that BA failed to make reasonable adjustments for her disability. The tribunal further ruled that BA had treated her unfavourably under the Equality Act by considering her absence for the operation when terminating her contract and in criticising her for not swapping shts. In his ruling, Employment Judge Oliver Hyams stated: Ms Drinkwater plainly did take into account in making her decision the fact that [Miss Scotland] had had some absences from work on account of sickness which was the result of having endometriosis, which [BA] accepted was a disability. Ms Drinkwater did that by criticising [Miss Scotland] for not swapping shts with the result that she did not, as far as Ms Drinkwater was concerned, exhibit what Ms Drinkwater would have regarded as a commendable spirit. That treatment of [Miss Scotland], ie that criticism, was made only as a result of her being unable to work because of the surgery which had been required to mitigate the effects of her disability. The tribunal said Cordelle would have been sacked anyway because of her lateness but awarded her compensation for injury to feelings. title: boy 15 sets up scotch
story: Boy, , sets up scotch egg business in lockdown - now says his dreams have come trueSchoolboy Oliver Jackson has cracked the key to success after taking over the once failing business Jawbone Scotch Egg Co from a family friend last year - and he isnt planning on stopping thereOliver Jackson found himself with some extra time of his hands - so got down to business Image: MEN MediaByAmber OConnorSam Elliott-Gibbs:,  Dec | commentsA young entrepreneur has made his dreams come true thanks to the launch of his lockdown scotch egg business. Hardworking schoolboy Oliver Jackson put his extra time to good use to get his tasty new-look enterprise off the ground.The -year-old took over the running of Jawbone Scotch Egg Co during lockdown last year after the one-time owner called it a day, Yorkshire Live report.Now the Sheffield ladaposs big idea is growing and growing - and he has set his sights on giving football fans their fill. The British favourite became a major talking point a year ago when the government introduce a apossubstantial mealapos rule for bars and pubs to allow them to open. Those in the hospitality industry demanded to knowa Scotch Egg qualied - and it finally got the thumbs up.  Now locals have given their taste approval and Oliver has big plans for the venture. He now sells upwards of one hundred scotch eggs from his small shop in Oughtibridge, Yorkshire, every Saturday. And after giving up his evenings and finding the aposhardapos balance between running the business while staying in school, Oliver appears to have cracked the key to success. His next goal is opening a shop near Sheffield Wednesdayaposs Hillsborough stadium to sell to hungry football fans on match days. Oliver said: All Iaposm thinking is how can I make it bigger. When I realised I could go for it myself it was a dream come true. Jawbone Scotch Egg Co now supplies four local cafes as well as selling from a converted shipping container on his familyaposs Greenhead House Farm. Flavours include Punjabi Curry, full English, and Port and Cranberry during the festive season. The boy plans to expand at his base, too.He hopes to add seating and will buy a coffee machine to attract even more customers.The products are handmade each week using locally sourced meat and eggs. title: brave boy born rare gap
story: Exclusive: Brave boy born with rare gap in oesophagus has dream come true meeting astronaut TimRiley Paxton had his first operation at just a few hours old and has had to battle multiple conditions throughout his young le but now when he struggles he’ll reflect back on the day his dream came true as he met astronaut Tim PeakeRiley was starstruck at his meeting with Tim Image: CollectByClaire OBoyleAssistant Features Editor Writer:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsWhen Riley Paxton, a space-mad youngster who has spent most of his le in and out of hospital, met astronaut Tim Peake, it was a moment that was truly out of this world. “Riley’s actual wish was go to the moon but when he realised we might struggle to make that happen the next best thing was to meet a real le astronaut,” says his mum Rachel. “So when he met Tim Peake he was over the moon. With everything  he’s got to contend with Riley also suffers from anxiety and the whole experience has helped a lot with that. “Even now when he’s struggling with his illness or feelings of anxiety he’ll reflect back on the day his dream came true to take his mind off the problems of the here and now. “We couldn’t have asked for a more amazing experience.” Riley’s dream day came about with the help of Make-A-Wish UK, this year’s Mirror Christmas Appeal charity, an organisation mum-of-two Rachel, , says has offered a ray of hope to the family during some of their most dficult times.“To have time away from what can feel like quite traumatic experiences makes a huge dference,” she says. Riley, now seven, was born prematurely at  weeks in September  weighing lbs oz. “Nothing was picked up during my pregnancy but once I was in labour Riley went into foetal distress and was delivered by emergency C-section,” recalls Rachel, from Newcastle.“Virtually as soon as he was born his journey with one surgery after another began. He had his first operation at just a few hours old.” Riley was diagnosed with TOF OA, two rare conditions that meant he was born with a gap in his oesophagus. Surgery quickly after delivery meant mum Rachel and dad David, , couldn’t kiss him for the first two days of his le. It was four days before they had their first cuddle.  “It was terrying from the beginning,” recalls Rachel. “Even though he had surgery straight away, it was weeks before the gap in his oesophagus was repaired and all that time he was in intensive care.” Riley was allowed home aged seven months old. By then the tot had also been diagnosed with a range of other health problems, including hemivertebra, a congenital condition which means parts of his spine are not properly developed. He also has dextrocardia which means his heart is slightly to the left of where it should be and he has suffered from respiratory illnesses over the years.  “He’s had a tough time,” says Rachel. “But he’s such a lovely boy.” The family’s challenges don’t stop there however, with Riley’s little sister Ruby-Leigh, five, also born with TOF OA. Both youngsters were even hospitalised at the same time. “Nothing was flagged during the pregnancy with Ruby-Leigh either,” says Rachel. “Over the years she’s had multiple surgeries on her oesophagus too. “They both go to mainstream school but it’s dficult, and particularly at this time of year. Very often one of both of them will end up with a respiratory illness as they have tracheomalacia, or a floppy airway, so even a common cold can end up with a chest infection that could lead to pneumonia.” By Jason Beattie For the majority of families this Christmas will be a joyous time of presents, food and fun. But for some children the festive season will be very dferent. Across the country there are more than , young people who are critically ill. Many will be spending what should be a special time of the year in hospital. Others will have to have treatment, scans or blood tests. With your help we can give them a Christmas that they will always remember. This year’s Mirror Christmas Appeal is raising funds for Make-A-Wish UK that helps seriously ill young people make their dreams come true.It could be they want to meet their hero or heroine or feed an animal at the zoo or travel to see Santa in Lapland. The money raised could help Joshua, six, who has severe epilepsy, achieve his wish of a bedroom makeover or Summer, also six, who has acute leukaemia and dreams of a bouncy castle. Each year Make-A-Wish helps hundreds of critically ill children achieve their letime’s ambition. But to make a wish come true takes an army of volunteers, supporters and donors. That’s why every penny you donate could make a dference. Granting a wish can transform a child’s le. It gives them something to look forward to. For others it provides a special memory which makes the treatment they need more bearable.It can also help their parents who, despite doing everything they can for their sick child, feel it is not enough. Jason Suckley, Make-A-Wish UK chief executive, said: “I met the family of a boy who was recovering from brain surgery. “His grandmother told me how dficult it had been for her to watch her daughter struggle with the challenges of her son’s condition.But while they were enjoying his wish together, her daughter turned to her and said, ‘There is still magic in this world isn’t there mum ’ . “That’s just one instance that illustrates how the power of a wish lies in sharing positive memories with loved ones. “Every donation from Mirror readers will help us create those memories – bringing joy to ill children and their families during the darkest of times.” Which is why the experience provided for Riley by Make-A-Wish in January  made such an impact. “I can’t put into words just what help they’ve given us,” says Rachel, who along with partner David is a full-time carer for her children. “Even now we talk about meeting Tim. Make-A-Wish gave us tickets to see him on stage in October and he gave Riley a shout-out. We can’t thank Tim and the charity enough.” Online: www.make-a-wish.org.uk mirror Text: To donate £ text the word LIGHT to . If you’d like to give £ but do not want marketing communications, text LIGHT NO to .You can text more than onceyou wish to donate more. Post: Please post cheques payable to MAKE-A-WISH UK to Freepost address below: Freepost Plus RUCS-LHTL-CJGU Make-A-Wish Mirror Appeal Make-A-Wish UK, Seventh Floor, Thames Tower, Station Road, Reading, Berkshire RG LX Now hopeful that little Ruby-Leigh is also eligible for a wish, Rachel, who dreams of becoming a nurse one day, hopes there might be even more special memories around the corner. “The wishes they grant make an impact far beyond the day they happen. They’re things families like ours truly treasure for a long time.” Read MoreRead MoreMost ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Tim PeakeHospitalsPregnancyGiving birthMirror Christmas appealXmas Appeal " data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: britains oldest learner driver applies
story: Exclusive: Britains oldest learner driver applies for provisional driving licence aged Leading motoring association MotorEasy found a  year old woman, a  year old and two  year olds among last year’s crop of would-be learners who got their provisional driving licencesThousands of would-be motorists decide to hit the road later in leImage: Getty Images iStockphotoByJeremy Armstrong:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsA doughty -year-old woman has been crowned Britain’s oldest learner driver. The plucky nonagenarian is among thousands of would-be motorists who decide to hit the road later in le, new research shows. Leading motoring association MotorEasy obtained a breakdown of the age profiles of people who applied for provisional driving licences in recent years and also found a  year old and two  year olds among last year’s crop of would-be learners. Duncan McClure Fisher, founder and CEO of MotorEasy, said: “The saying goes that you are as young as you feel, and age doesn’t have to be a barrier to achieving something as big as passing your driving test. Many people find learning to drive a little daunting, so anyone who decides to take the plunge should be applauded no matter their vintage. These surprising figures show that rather than being cowed by their age and events such as the Covid pandemic, these plucky pensioners are embracing their independence and living le to the full. As long as you have the physical and mental ability to become a capable and responsible driver, it shouldn’t matter whether you begin at  or .”  MotorEasy asked the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agencyfor a full breakdown of the ages and genders of people who applied for and been granted a provisional driving licence between  and . The statistics show  is always the most popular age for learner drivers to begin the process, with  being the legal age to drive on UK roads. Some , learners aged  applied for a provisional licence so far in , with the next most common age being  with , applicants. This year, a total of  people over the pension age of  decided to learn how to drive.This includes six people between the ages of  and  – the oldest applicant in  – and  applicants between the ages of  and .Last year, the -year-old woman led the way in the oldest learner driver stakes, followed by two -year-olds and one -year-old.There is no maximum age to learn how to drive in the UK, but once you reach the age of  your licence expires and you have to renew it every three years, rather than every  years for under s. Since , there has been one -year-old applicant, one aged , two aged , one aged  and four aged .The oldest, just a year away from receiving a congratulatory telegram from the Queen, would legally have been able to drive as long ago as  – the year World War Two broke out.Her Majesty, , is among those still driving in their later years, with the monarch spotted behind the wheel of a Jaguar estate close toWindsor Castle just last month.Her late husband, Prince Philip, only gave up his licence at the age of  – two years before he died.The DVLA does not disclose the locations of learner drivers as it could lead to identication.For more information, visit https:www.motoreasy  Read MoreRead MoreMost ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Driving testMotoring mishaps" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: covid rates among elderly lowest
story: Covid rates among elderly at lowest level since JULY - see breakdown of age groupsThe figures, from the Health Security Agency , may reflect the impact of booster doses of Covid- vaccine, which began to be rolled out to double-jabbed people in the oldest groups from the end of SeptemberThe government has already extended its booster jab programme to all eligible adults Image: Getty ImagesByIan JonesAlice Peacock:,  Dec , may reflect the impact of booster doses of Covid- vaccine, which began to be rolled out to double-jabbed people in the oldest groups from the end of September" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _Wrapped-Up-Warm.jpg" data-tracking"facebook|share|top", may reflect the impact of booster doses of Covid- vaccine, which began to be rolled out to double-jabbed people in the oldest groups from the end of September" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _Wrapped-Up-Warm.jpg" data-tracking"twitter|share|top", may reflect the impact of booster doses of Covid- vaccine, which began to be rolled out to double-jabbed people in the oldest groups from the end of September" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _Wrapped-Up-Warm.jpg" data-tracking"whatsapp|share|top" Covid-case rates among the oldest age groups in England have fallen to their lowest level for nearly five months, figures show, as rates for these groups fall for the fth week in a row.For those in their s and over, a total of . new cases per , people were recorded in the week to November . Some . cases per , people were recorded for  to -year-olds. For both age groups they are the lowest rates of new cases since the week to July . It is the fth week in a row that rates for these groups have fallen. The figures, from the Health Security Agency , may reflect the impact of booster doses of Covid- vaccine, which began to be rolled out to double-jabbed people in the oldest groups from the end of September.  Figures released by the government earlier this week said more than  million booster jabs have been given across the UK. The government has already extended its booster jab programme to all eligible adults, who can expect to receive their booster by the end of January. While cases are currently low in the UK, there are concerns about the new Omicron iant - whether it could be more transmissible or more resistant to vaccines. Medical experts have advised caution and new restrictions were put in place as a result of the new strain. Meanwhile, rates of infection have also fallen among all other age groups, including schoolchildren. Some . cases per , people aged five to nine were recorded in the latest week, down from . a week earlier. The figure for  to -year-olds has dropped from . to ..  Covid rates for both these groups had risen in the previous two weeks, which coincided with theof pupils to school following the half-term holiday. Across England, rates have dropped in all regions except London. In the capital, rates of infection have risen slightly, from . to .. The South East has the highest rate, at . cases per , people, while Yorkshire and Humber has the lowest, at .. news uk-news detective-says-dad-stepmum-who-"Arthur Labinjo-Hughes cries no-one loves me in harrowing audioByMartin Fricker:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec Tragic Arthur Labinjo-Hughes would still be alivethe Covid- lockdown had not happened, detectives believe. The six-year-old was living with his paternal grandparents, who “loved and cherished him”, when the pandemic hit. But his dad Thomas Hughes decided to move in with girlfriend Emma Tustin when the country was plunged into lockdown.Today his evil stepmum convicted of murdering the defenceless child after a horric campaign of abuse, while his dad was found guilty of manslaughter.Det Insp Laura Harrison, of West Midlands Police, said it “was the worst decision that could have been made”. “If only Hughes had left Arthur with his grandparents who absolutely doted on him, loved him and cherished him,” she told the Mirror. “The manipulation and the toxic relationship between Tustin and Hughes meant the family were cut out of Arthur’s le and didnapost play a part. “The lockdown meant professionals didn’t have the opportunity to monitor him in the same way they would do with children normally. “I do think that lockdown contributed. “The professionals who would ordinarily have been involved in Arthur’s le, such as teachers, weren’t having that contact with him and spotting changes in his behaviour or bruises on his body. “Tustin and Hughes cut off family members so Arthur was no longer seeing or speaking to him. “And when social workers went out to Tustin’s home there was an absolute manipulation of them by the defendants. “It was the only day when Arthur was allowed to play in the garden and he presented very dferently as a result. “When the professionals did speak to him they weren’t picking up on the signs they would have donehe had been segregated in a hallway. “Tustin and Hughes pulled the wood over the eyes of the professionals. They didn’t want children’s services involved.” Specialist grief counsellors were drafted in to help police left traumatised by Arthur’s death.  Veteran detectives were left in tears as they watched CCTV footage of the helpless youngster alone in his family home. They also discovered harrowing evidence that Arthur had been sadistically poisoned with salt by his dad and step-mum. DI Harrison described it as the “most traumatic” case she had ever investigated. She compared his death to the murder of Daniel Pelka, the tragic four-year-old boy killed by his mum and step-dad in . In both cases the children were deliberately poisoned with salt to increase the suffering before their deaths. “I knew when we started it was a horric case, but there have been moments that have just completely got me,” she said.  “Everyone involved has found it really haunting having to witness and experience the evil and horric torture that Arthur was subjected to. “There are real similarities with Daniel Pelka, definitely in terms of salt poisoning. “I’d not heard of it before in child cruelty cases and it’s been really hard to comprehend. But it is a haunting parallel. “A physical assault is one thing - but it’s very devious and manipulative to dose a child up with salt. It’s another level of evil. “It could only have been done as another way to control Arthur - an extra punishment. “We think maybe they did it to make him more thirsty but we don’t know because they’ve never given us an explanation. “It’s been really dficult for the officers who have to sit for hours watching CCTV footage of Arthur being isolated.  “I arranged for a trauma counsellor to come in to explain the emotions people might be experiencing and to teach coping mechanisms they could put in place. “They have been able to independently see the counsellor without the rest of the team knowing. “We don’t ordinarily get faced with CCTV like this. “The footage really got to the heart of what Arthur was being subjected to and thataposs why it’s been so hard-hitting and dferent to similar cases. “When you add in the  recordings of Arthur in distress and the brutal text messages, it sets it apart from the Pelka and Baby P cases. “We’ve been reliant on medical expert opinion and it’s been crucial. “But the actual emotional element of this case has been proved by that CCTV or hearing audio clips where he is calling out for family members, calling out for food or water, and that nobody loves him. “We all know children in our lives. You just cannot comprehend anybody being able to neglect a child over such a sustained period of time. “It was not a sudden loss of control, it was a well thought-out campaign of abuse, both physically and psychologically, towards Arthur.” DI Harrison said it was “hard to comprehend” how Hughes and Tustin tried to blame Arthur for his fatal injuries. She said: “They’ve blamed each other and they’ve blamed Arthur as well. “How can a six-year-old boy be responsible for what happened  We know he couldn’t have inflicted his fatal injuries himself. “They are both equally responsible. Although Tustin killed Arthur, Hughes encouraged the killing by actions.” The sheer cruelty of the couple was played out in the courtroom over two months. Texts between them showed their feelings towards the little boy, whose mother was previously jailed for the manslaughter of her boyfriend. In brutal messages, Hughes told Tustin to aposjust endapos Arthur and also apostake his jaw offapos and aposgagapos him. He also threatened to apostake his neck offapos and aposdash my food off his headapos. The day before the child died, his dad texted about paying someone to aposdig Arthuraposs graveapos. Tustin was equally vile, the court was told. In one message she said aposf****** launch this lying little f***apos and in another she warned she was aposgoing to chin this little c***apos. title: families home schooling sick kids
story: Families home schooling sick kids to protect them face prosecution in bonkers ruleGetting back to normal has left millions of clinically vulnerable people behind but, rather than recognising the dilemma faced by vulnerable families, Education Secretary Nadhim Zahawi has doubled down on the Tory Government’s position, Toby, and Phobe,  pictured at their home in Whitchurch, Bristol. The children are currently not in school due to concerns over covid and Toby’s type  diabetes condition." content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _RGP_MDM_Morris_.jpg" width"" "" The Morris family in Somerset - Charlie Morris with children Finley,  , Toby, and Phoebe,  at their home in Whitchurch, Bristol Image: Rowan Grfiths   Daily MirrorByRos Wynne JonesReal Britain columnistClaire Donnelly:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsSarah Brooks has chronic ­rheumatoid arthritis. Like many people on immunosuppressant drugs, she is double-vaccinated but hasn’t developed any ­antibodies to Covid-. Her four-year-old daughter, Ella, has a rare type of epilepsy that can be ­triggered by a virus or a fever. With Covid rates rising, and the new Omicron iant gaining ground, Mrs Brooks has taken the decision to home school her three children. But – under current government rules – now faces being fined. “We were invited for a meeting with the attendance officer and were told we face fines and or prosecution,” says Mrs Brooks . “On the same day we got a letter saying that the school itself was at the centre of a Covid outbreak. It’s bonkers.” The family have now got in touch with the Good Law Project, who have sent a pre-action letter to the local council challenging the decision to enforce attendance. Getting “back to normal” has left millions of clinically vulnerable people behind. At one time .million were official “shielders”. One in four of them has never stopped according to ONS figures. Now they are just people who can’t go out, but have no extra support. Last week, the number of pupils absent from school in England because of Covid rose by about %. Some , state-school pupils were absent with confirmed or suspected cases on November . Rather than recognising the dilemma faced by vulnerable families, the Secretary of State for Education, Nadhim Zahawi, has doubled down on the Government’s position with a letter to school leaders about “maximising” school attendance. “We are at a crucial point in the pandemic and must collectively act now to ensure lower levels of attendance do not become the accepted norm,” the letter says. “I hope you agree on the urgency.” For the Morris family in Somerset, the letter was devastating. Toby Morris, , has had Type  diabetes since he was a baby. He is a brittle diabetic who needs round-the-clock monitoring. The Morris’s are having to homeschool his sister, Phoebe, seven, and brother Finlay, , because of the risk of them catching the virus at school. Finlay, who himself has asthma, shares a bunkbed with Toby. And their mum, Abi, , has an immune condition. “Because the Government is saying no one has to shield and children should attend as normal, we’re stuck in this nightmare,” their dad Charlie,, explains. “The bubbles, isolating, all the things schools were doing to keep children safe, it’s all gone out of the window. “There are thousands of families like ours put in a position where schools are saying they can’t authorise any absence because it’s meant to now be attendance as normal – but because there are vulnerable people in our family that isn’t safe for us. “School is important – I’m a former teacher. But an education is no goodyou’re dead or suffering a chronic illness as a result of a nasty infection. Our son’s already suffered enough living with a le-long, le-limiting condition.” The family is also being supported by the Good Law Project after claiming their local MP, Jacob Rees-Mogg, failed to reply to them. This week, the Government ­introduced masks into communal areas in schools, but stopped short of further mitigations like increasing ventilation, classroom bubbles, masks in classrooms and further access to vaccinations for children. Many Year  children won’t turn  until long after winter. Even then, the vaccination programme for children is grindingly slow. Nadhim Zahawi recently met with Miriam Cates, a Tory MP and education committee member who believes “Covid isn’t a risk to children”. Andrew Lewer MP tweeted “Miriam Cates MP  I met with @nadhimzahawi about face masks in schools  our aspiration to phase them out.” Cates is known for her ­opposition to masks because “showing our faces is part of being human”. She’s also called for an end to regular testing of schoolchildren without symptoms, and says there’s “no rush” for vaccines in schools.For Ella Brooks, at home in the Midlands, catching Covid could be a death sentence. Her rare form of epilepsy means she suffers intense seizures particularly when she has a fever. These can start in her sleep and cause her to stop breathing. “Once again we are behind Wales and Scotland in terms of mitigations being adopted, despite Covid currently running rampant through most schools in England,” her mum says. “The message seems to be ‘attendance at all costs’ – but for us, that cost could be someone’s le.” A Department for Education spokesperson said: “The best place for young people is in the classroom, it is vital for their education and mental health which is a priority. “All children should be supported to continue to attend school and our guidance to schools about attendance of clinically vulnerable children has been clear throughout. In line with guidance every child aged  and over with specic underlying health conditions has been offered the vaccine.” No one wants ato lockdown home schooling. And yet failing to use masks alongside mitigations like ventilation will likely end in soaring cases. Yesterday, Gwynedd in North Wales, announced ato online learning after a spike in cases. More councils may soon be following suit. “There’s this  argument you’re pro-freedom or pro-lockdown but it’s not that simple,” mum Sarah says. “We don’t want lockdown and we want schools to stay open, but we need them to be made safer and at the moment, for families like ours, they’re not. As parents it’s really stressful.” For her the choice comes down to one thing. “I’ve sat at my daughter’s bedside, watched her struggling. Her condition can be le-threatening and I have to do what I can to prevent that.”Read MoreRead MoreMost ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Tory GovernmentJacob Rees-MoggNadhim ZahawiEducationSchoolsMental healthArthritisPoliticsEpilepsyCoronavirusCoronavirus lockdown" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: first aston martin db6 vantage
story: First Aston Martin DB Vantage restored to glory after  years languishing in garageAston Martin DB Vantage is now worth £, after being put in storage in  and forgotten about until  when it was bought by classic car enthusiast John CookThe restored car is worth £, Image: Max Willcock BNPSByJoseph Draper:,  Dec | commentsThe first Aston Martin DB Vantage ever made has been restored to its former glory after it spent  years languishing in a garage. The incredibly rare time capsule, that is now worth £,, was the first to leave the production line in September . The show car toured for , miles across the country and was used by the carmakers to advertise their state-of-the-art creation. But after its star-studded first years, the Aston passed into private hands and was put in storage in  where it was left to fall apart. The Vantage was forgotten about until  when it was bought by classic car enthusiast John Cook at an auction.  He spent a whopping £, on an extensive restoration project, ing the car to its factory condition with Fiesta red paintwork and black leather interior. It even includes original copies of magazine reviews, its parts catalogue, instruction book, owner logbook, and test certicates. Charles Ramsey, owner of Classic Connection in Burley, Hants, where the car has ben consigned for sale, said it was the ‘rarest DB in existence’.  He said: “The most impressive thing about this car is that it was the first DB Vantage - and only the third DB - ever to leave the production line. “It was used as a factory demonstration for advertisements and magazine reviews making it very rare to a collector. “The car has been fully restored to its original Fiesta red and all its specications compared to others of its kind which were often changed.  “The history file includes magazine reviews of the car, its owner logbook, instruction book, and factory build sheets. “It’s a blessing this piece of Aston Martin history was discovered after lying dormant and restored to such a remarkable degree”. Mr Cook handed the motor over to Aston Services Dorset, the officially-appointed restorers of vintage Astons, for the restoration project. Only , DBs were made at the Aston Martin factory in Newport Pagnell, Bucks, between  and . The Vantage iant came out in  but only  models were made. The Vantages, which offered a more powerful performance, were even more exclusive. They had a .-litre straight six-cylinder engine that could deliver bhp compared bhp that standard DBs had. Mr Cook, , who is also from Burley, said: “Cars from this period often got to the stage where their value dropped and owners forgot about them which seems to have been the case with this one. “When I bought it, it was in a serious state of disrepair and I gave it to Aston Services Dorset to undergo a £, restoration. “It is such a special car which is so perfect and I want to give it to someone  to enjoy. “I’ve got another project in mind so I needed to clear the decks to get myself ready for it. “I have a real passion for finding old things and bringing them back to how they originally were.” Read MoreRead MoreMost ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Aston MartinCars" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news graphics-show-mutated-omicron-iant-"Omicron: Health minister says Christmas will hopefully not be ruinedByDave BurkeSenior News Reporter:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | comments Worrying graphics show just how mutated the newly-emerged Omicron iant is - as scientists around the world scramble to find outvaccines work against it. Illustrations released by the Genomics UK Consortiumshow that it has a worrying  mutations on its spike protein. By comparison Delta - which tore through the population last winter and has since become the worldaposs dominant strain - has seven. Experts have said Omicron, which was first identied by scientists in South Africa, is the most mutated Covid iant they have yet encountered. This morning a spokesman for the UK Health Security Agency told The Mirror that targeted testing is being carried out for the iant.  This means that not every positive PCR test is screened for the new strain.At the weekend Boris Johnson announced a range of measures aimed at halting Omicronaposs spread, including compulsory PCR testing for all travellers arriving in the UK from abroad.  Contacts of those identied as having the strain are also required to isolate for  days, regardless of whether they have vaccinated. Officials say it is too early to tell how worried we should be about the iant, with Brits urged to show caution.  The strain has been classied as of concern by the World Health Organisation . It is feared that Omicron could prove resistant to vaccines because of the number of mutations in its spike protein. This affects how it responds to antibodies in the immune system, and the way it enters human cells. This week South African Raquel Viana, Head of Science at one of South Africaaposs biggest private testing labs, said she had a sinking feeling when she discovered the new strain while genetically testing positive swabs in the country.  She told Reuters: I was quite shocked at what I was seeing. I questioned whether something had gone wrong in the process.Early indications show most Omicroncoronavirus cases are mild, the World Health Organisation has said. The official believes there is no evidence to suggest the efficacy of vaccines reduces when battling against the new iant.The organisation, quoted by Reuters, suggested most cases so far examined are not severe. They cautiously added there is still a lot not yet known about the new strain. title: how having mould house affects
story: How having mould in the house affects your health - and how to get rid of it safelyMould and damp can be dangerous, especially for the more vulnerable members of your household - learn how to to tackle the problem that affects % of all homes in the UKAround  per cent of British homes suffer with damp and far more with mould Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByHarry ThompsonSEO Writer:,  Dec | comments Having a cosy, warm place to go in winter is vital - but musky carpets, a brown stain on the ceiling and condensation on the windows as a draft whistles through the house can put an end to it very quickly. However a damp cold home is not only extremely unpleasant, it can also be very bad for your health. Government data has found that in the two years to March , % of all homes in the UK had damp in one room or more while between % and % are thought to have black mould.Damp and mould appear when there is excess moisture in the home, which can be caused by anything from leaking pipes and rising damp on ground floors to leaking ceilings and poor ventilation. How does mould in the house affect my health  Damp in the home can have a array of negative health effects, causing respiratory infections, asthma and allergies. It produces a number of substances that disagree with the human body, including irritants, allergens and, on occasion, toxic substances. If you inhale or touch mould it can lead to allergic reactions including sneezing, a runny nose, skin rashes and red eyes. In more severe cases it can directly lead to asthma attacks. It affects some worse than others with babies, children, the elderly all more sensitive to it.It can also affect people with pre-existing medical conditions that are made worse by its presence. They include people with skin conditions like eczema, respiratory problems like asthma and allergies or those with a weakened immune system like someone undergoing chemotherapy.How to safely get rid of mould from your homeAccording to homeserve, getting rid of mould on walls can be achieved using a number of dferent chemicals including baking soda, white distilled vinegar or % concentration of hydrogen peroxide. They should be applied to the area and left for a time before being scrubbed.It is crucial you find you where the excess moisture is coming from - once you know the source you can begin to take steps to mitigate the effects or solve the issue completely. Getting this done may sometimes need professional help, although smaller amounts can be done yourself. If your home is newly built yet still damp it could be that the water used in its construction, like in wall plaster, is still drying out. How do you stop mould growing in your home  Homeserve suggest a number of top tips for preventing mould from taking hold, they say: Open windows every day to let fresh air in and moisture out Close the door of the room you’re ventilating to keep the rest of the house warm and prevent moisture escaping to other parts Open a window or use an extractor fan when showering, cooking or using a tumble dryer When you’re not showering or cooking, leave internal doors open to let air flow freely around your house Dry any washing outside when possible If you do dry washing inside, open a window and close the door of the room it’s hanging in If you have window vents, leave them open permanently Use a dehumidier and moisture traps on windowsills to remove damp from the air Dry any condensation from windows and windowsills Clear out roof gutters regularly to avoid water overflowing onto your walls Check roof tiles and fascia boards and repair any leaks or rotting wood Check that your damp-proof course is above the ground level of your home Fix plumbing leaks quickly and dry the area.
